record.text:
「AIが解明！よく使う言葉の意味進化」

📌 ニュース： 最新の研究で、頻繁に使われる単語ほど多くの意味を持つ「意味‐頻度の法則」が多言語で共通することが示されました。この研究では、AIが文章を分析し、単語の使われ方を数値化する「単語ベクトル」を用いて、辞書に頼らず言葉の意味の多さを評価しました。…

external.description: 📌 ニュース： 最新の研究で、頻繁に使われる単語ほど多くの意味を持つ「意味‐頻度の法則」が多言語で共通することが示されました。この研究では、AIが文章を分析し、単語の使われ方を数値化する「単語ベクトル」を用いて、辞書に頼らず言葉の意味の多さを評価しました。 結果、英語や日本語など多くの言語で、使われる頻度が高い単語ほど文脈が広がり、意味が豊かになることが確認されました。さらに、AIの性能によってこの関係が影響を受けることも発見され、AIの理解力を測る新たな手法としてこの法則が期待されています。言葉が効率的に進化し、多様な意味を持つ理由も明らかになりました。 この記事のポイントは以下の3つです✨: 頻繁に使われる言葉の法則📚 研究チームは「よく使われる単語ほど意味が多くなる」という法則が、多くの言語に共通していることを発見しました。この法則は「意味‐頻度の法則」と呼ばれます。 AIによる新しい分析方法🤖 研究では、AIを使って単語の意味の豊かさを測定しました。単語が多様な文脈で使われるほど、その意味の広がりが大きいとされました。 AIの発展への影響🚀 この研究結果は、AIが言葉の多義性を理解できているかを評価する新しい方法として活用される可能性があります。言葉の普遍的な性質の理解は、AIの性能向上や言語学習にも役立つでしょう。 以上のポイントが、この研究の重要な成果です！ ※以下、出典元 ▶ 元記事を読む

record.text:
「クラシック名曲深堀り」次回8/31「ばらの騎士」解剖！

2025年8月19日、銀座にあるオーディオショップ「サウンドクリエイト」で、人気イベント「クラシック名曲深堀り」が開催されました。このイベントは、毎回1曲のクラシック音楽の名曲を取り上げ、その深い理解を促すもので、オーディオ評論家の山之内正氏と哲学者の黒崎政男氏が対談を行います。 この対談では、選ばれた名曲の作曲時代背景、音楽の技法、さらに録音手法などを掘り下げることで、聴衆は作品の本質をより深く理解することができます。クラシック音楽の魅力を引き出すこのイベントは、多くの音楽ファンやオーディオ愛好者にとって、貴重な体験となります。…

external.description: 2025年8月19日、銀座にあるオーディオショップ「サウンドクリエイト」で、人気イベント「クラシック名曲深堀り」が開催されました。このイベントは、毎回1曲のクラシック音楽の名曲を取り上げ、その深い理解を促すもので、オーディオ評論家の山之内正氏と哲学者の黒崎政男氏が対談を行います。 この対談では、選ばれた名曲の作曲時代背景、音楽の技法、さらに録音手法などを掘り下げることで、聴衆は作品の本質をより深く理解することができます。クラシック音楽の魅力を引き出すこのイベントは、多くの音楽ファンやオーディオ愛好者にとって、貴重な体験となります。 「クラシック名曲深堀り」は、音楽の楽しみを広げる一環として、毎回新しい発見を与えてくれる機会です。興味がある方は、次回のイベントにもぜひ参加してみてください。 🧠 編集部より： 銀座のオーディオショップ「サウンドクリエイト」と人気イベント「クラシック名曲深堀り」 開催概要 「クラシック名曲深堀り」は、銀座のオーディオショップ「サウンドクリエイト」が主催するイベントシリーズで、毎回1曲のクラシック名曲を掘り下げていきます。オーディオ評論家の山之内正氏と哲学者の黒崎政男氏の対談を通じて、音楽の持つ魅力を新たに発見できます。 イベントの内容 作曲された時代背景: それぞれの曲が生まれた背景や、歴史的な影響を探ります。例えば、ベートーヴェンの交響曲第5番は、ナポレオン戦争の影響を受けた時代に作曲されました。 作曲技法: 各楽曲の構成や使用楽器、そしてその独自の技法について掘り下げます。これにより、作品の魅力がより深く理解できるようになります。 録音手法: クラシック音楽は録音技術によって新しい楽しみが加わります。歴史的な録音と最新のデジタル技術の違いについても言及されます。 豆知識 音楽と哲学: クラシック音楽には、作曲家の思想や哲学が色濃く反映されています。たとえば、シューベルトのメロディには人間の感情深さが顕著に表れています。 オーディオの進化: レコードからデジタル音源への移行は、聴き方を大きく変えました。高解像度音源が普及することで、音楽の体験も変わりつつあります。 参加方法 イベントの参加は事前予約が必要です。詳細は公式サイトをチェックしてください。 サウンドクリエイト公式サイト このイベントは、クラシック音楽をもっと楽しみたい方や、音楽の深い理解を求める方にとって、絶好の機会となるでしょう。音楽を楽しむだけでなく、その背後にあるストーリーを知ることで、より豊かな体験が得られます。興味がある方はぜひ参加してみてください！ キーワード: 深堀り クラシック音楽 をAmazonで探す オーディオ機器 をAmazonで探す 音楽評論書 をAmazonで探す ※以下、出典元 ▶ 元記事を読む
external.title: 「クラシック名曲深堀り」次回8/31「ばらの騎士」解剖！

Clearly China doesn't have enough compute for scaled AI today:
 - GPT-OSS, Llama [US]: optimized for cheaper inference
 - R1, Kimi K2, Qwen [China]: optimized for cheaper training

With China's population reducing inference costs is more important, and that means more training.
Transcribe audio with @groq.com.

I spent the weekend hanging out with a group of friends. A question we asked was what dreams did we have that we gave up on?

When I was 18, I had two dreams:

1) Be an astronaut 
2) Build AI chips

I didn’t give up on one of them. 😀

Introduction: The proliferation of Child Sexual Abuse Material (CSAM) on the dark web presents a persistent and technically challenging problem for cybersecurity professionals and law enforcement.…

external.description: Introduction: The proliferation of Child Sexual Abuse Material (CSAM) on the dark web presents a persistent and technically challenging problem for cybersecurity professionals and law enforcement. CIRCL's new public onion lookup service provides a critical tool for automating the detection and filtering of these malicious Tor hidden services, shifting the paradigm from reactive analysis to proactive defense. This technical deep dive explores how to integrate this API into security operations, from threat intelligence platforms to custom Python scripts, enabling analysts to build scalable detection pipelines.

Cybersecurity’s Silent Weakness: Why Human Behavior Is the Biggest Threat in 2025

Introduction For years, organizations have invested billions in cutting-edge security tools, next-generation firewalls, AI-driven detection systems, and cloud security frameworks. Yet, despite this technological…

external.description: Introduction For years, organizations have invested billions in cutting-edge security tools, next-generation firewalls, AI-driven detection systems, and cloud security frameworks. Yet, despite this technological progress, the majority of cyber breaches still trace back to one factor: human behavior. Attackers are no longer solely exploiting technical vulnerabilities—they are exploiting people. This shift has forced businesses to rethink their approach to security, recognizing that culture, clarity, and communication may be just as critical as software and systems.
external.title: Cybersecurity’s Silent Weakness: Why Human Behavior Is the Biggest Threat in 2025

external.description: Dubai, UAE; 14 August 2025: Zand, an AI-powered Fintech and financial services group in the United Arab Emirates, has announced the signing of a strategic agreement with Mastercard to collaborate on enhancing cross-border payment solutions. record.text: England from the beginning
x.com/i/grok/share...

external.description: The history of England is a vast and complex tale, spanning thousands of years from prehistoric times to the modern era. Below is a concise overview, organized into key periods, covering the major developments, events, and transformations that shaped England. Given the broad scope, I'll focus on the most significant moments and transitions while keeping the narrative clear and engaging.  Prehistoric England (Before 43 CE) Earliest Inhabitants (c. 800,000 BCE–3,000 BCE): Archaeological evidence, like tools found in Happisburgh, Norfolk, suggests human presence in Britain as early as 800,000 years ago. These were likely Homo antecessor or other early humans. During the Neolithic period (c. 4,000–2,500 BCE), farming arrived, and iconic monuments like Stonehenge were built, indicating complex social structures and religious practices. Bronze and Iron Ages (c. 2,500 BCE–43 CE): The Bronze Age saw the use of metal tools and trade networks, while the Iron Age introduced Celtic tribes, known as Britons, who built hill forts (e.g., Maiden Castle) and spoke Celtic languages. Society was tribal, with no centralized "England" yet.  Roman Britain (43 CE–410 CE) Roman Conquest (43 CE): Emperor Claudius invaded Britain, establishing Roman rule. The Britons, led by figures like Boudicca (who rebelled in 60–61 CE), resisted but were subdued. Roman Britain saw the construction of roads, towns (e.g., Londinium), and Hadrian’s Wall (122 CE) to defend against northern tribes. Roman Society and Decline: Romans introduced urban planning, Christianity (by the 4th century), and a market economy. By 410 CE, as the Roman Empire weakened, troops were withdrawn, leaving Britain vulnerable to invasions.  Anglo-Saxon England (410–1066) Anglo-Saxon Settlement (5th–6th Centuries): After Roman withdrawal, Germanic tribes (Angles, Saxons, Jutes) migrated to Britain, pushing Celtic Britons west. By the 7th century, kingdoms like Wessex, Mercia, and Northumbria emerged, often warring for dominance. This period is often called the "Dark Ages" due to limited written records. Christianization and Culture (7th–8th Centuries): Christianity spread, with figures like St. Augustine (sent by Pope Gregory I in 597) converting King Æthelberht of Kent. Monasteries became centers of learning, producing works like Bede’s Ecclesiastical History of the English People. Viking Invasions (8th–11th Centuries): From the late 8th century, Vikings raided and settled, establishing the Danelaw in eastern England. King Alfred the Great of Wessex (r. 871–899) resisted, unifying Anglo-Saxon kingdoms and laying the foundation for a single "England." Late Anglo-Saxon Period: By the 10th century, Alfred’s successors, like Æthelstan, became kings of a unified England. However, Viking raids resumed, and by 1016, Cnut, a Danish king, ruled England, integrating it into a North Sea empire.  Norman Conquest and Medieval England (1066–1485) Norman Conquest (1066): William the Conqueror defeated King Harold II at the Battle of Hastings, fundamentally reshaping England. Norman rule introduced feudalism, French-speaking nobility, and the Domesday Book (1086), a survey of land and resources. High Middle Ages (11th–13th Centuries): England saw castle-building, the growth of towns, and conflicts like the Anarchy (1135–1154), a civil war over succession. The Magna Carta (1215), forced on King John by barons, limited royal power and laid foundations for constitutional governance. Late Middle Ages (13th–15th Centuries): England faced the Black Death (1348–1350), which killed nearly half the population, causing social upheaval. The Hundred Years’ War (1337–1453) with France saw victories like Agincourt (1415) but ended in English defeat. The Wars of the Roses (1455–1487), a civil war between the houses of Lancaster and York, ended with Henry Tudor’s victory at Bosworth (1485), founding the Tudor dynasty.  Tudor England (1485–1603) Henry VII and Stability (r. 1485–1509): Henry VII restored order, strengthened the monarchy, and centralized power. Henry VIII (r. 1509–1547): His break with the Catholic Church over his divorce from Catherine of Aragon led to the English Reformation, establishing the Church of England. He also dissolved monasteries, seizing their wealth. Elizabeth I (r. 1558–1603): Elizabeth’s reign was a golden age, marked by the defeat of the Spanish Armada (1588), exploration (e.g., Sir Francis Drake), and cultural flourishing (e.g., Shakespeare). Her religious settlement balanced Protestant and Catholic interests, though tensions persisted.  Stuart England and Civil War (1603–1714) Early Stuarts (1603–1649): James I united the crowns of England and Scotland, but religious and political tensions grew. His son, Charles I, clashed with Parliament over taxation and power, leading to the English Civil War (1642–1651). Civil War and Commonwealth: Parliamentarians, led by Oliver Cromwell, defeated royalists. Charles I was executed in 1649, and England became a Commonwealth (republic) under Cromwell. After his death, the monarchy was restored in 1660 under Charles II. Glorious Revolution (1688): James II’s Catholic leanings led to his overthrow by William of Orange and Mary II in a bloodless coup, establishing a constitutional monarchy with the Bill of Rights (1689). Act of Union (1707): England and Scotland united to form Great Britain under Queen Anne.  Georgian and Imperial Britain (1714–1837) Hanoverian Rule: The German House of Hanover took the throne with George I. Political power shifted to Parliament, with figures like Robert Walpole, Britain’s first prime minister, shaping governance. Industrial Revolution (late 18th century): England led the world in industrialization, with innovations in textiles, steam power, and transport (e.g., railways). Cities like Manchester grew rapidly, but social inequalities sparked unrest. Empire and Wars: Britain expanded its empire, particularly in India and North America, but lost the American colonies (1776–1783). The Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815) ended with Britain’s victory at Waterloo, cementing its global dominance.  Victorian Era (1837–1901) Queen Victoria’s Reign: Victoria’s long rule saw Britain at its imperial peak, controlling vast territories in Africa, Asia, and beyond. The British Empire became the largest in history. Social and Political Reforms: The Reform Acts (1832, 1867, 1884) expanded voting rights, while social reforms addressed child labor, education, and public health. The abolition of slavery (1833) was a moral triumph. Cultural and Scientific Advances: Writers like Dickens, scientists like Darwin, and engineers like Brunel defined the era. Railways and telegraphs transformed communication and travel.  20th Century: World Wars and Decline of Empire (1901–2000) Edwardian Era and World War I (1901–1918): Edward VII’s reign was prosperous, but World War I (1914–1918) cost millions of lives and strained the economy. The war ended with Britain victorious but weakened. Interwar Years: The 1920s and 1930s saw economic struggles, the Great Depression, and the rise of women’s suffrage (1918, 1928). Political extremism grew in Europe, setting the stage for World War II. World War II (1939–1945): Under Winston Churchill, Britain resisted Nazi Germany, enduring the Blitz and contributing to the Allied victory. Post-war, the welfare state was established with the NHS (1948) and other reforms. Decolonization and Post-War Recovery: The British Empire dismantled as colonies like India (1947) gained independence. Immigration from former colonies diversified England’s population. Late 20th Century: Margaret Thatcher’s (1979–1990) and Tony Blair’s (1997–2007) premierships shaped modern England. Thatcher’s free-market policies and privatization were divisive, while Blair’s "New Labour" emphasized social equality and devolution (e.g., Scottish Parliament).  Modern England (2000–Present) 21st Century Challenges: England faced terrorism (e.g., 2005 London bombings), economic crises (2008 financial crash), and political division. The 2016 Brexit referendum led to the UK’s exit from the EU in 2020, reshaping trade and identity. Cultural and Social Evolution: England remains a global cultural hub, with London as a financial and multicultural center. Issues like climate change, immigration, and inequality dominate contemporary debates. Political Landscape: Devolution has given more power to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, while England navigates its role within the UK and globally.  Key Themes in England’s History Unification: From fragmented tribes to a unified kingdom under Alfred and Æthelstan, England’s identity coalesced over centuries. Conquest and Resistance: Invasions (Roman, Viking, Norman) and internal conflicts (Civil War, Wars of the Roses) shaped governance and society. Global Influence: From the British Empire to modern soft power (e.g., BBC, Premier League), England has long punched above its weight. Adaptation: England’s ability to adapt—through industrialization, democratic reforms, or decolonization—has ensured its resilience.  This summary condenses thousands of years into key moments. If you’d like a deeper dive into any period, event, or theme (e.g., the Reformation, Industrial Revolution, or Brexit), let me know, and I can expand with more detail or focus on specific aspects!

These were likely Homo antecessor or other early humans. During the Neolithic period (c. 4,000–2,500 BCE), farming arrived, and iconic monuments like Stonehenge were built, indicating complex social structures and religious practices. Bronze and Iron Ages (c. 2,500 BCE–43 CE): The Bronze Age saw the use of metal tools and trade networks, while the Iron Age introduced Celtic tribes, known as Britons, who built hill forts (e.g., Maiden Castle) and spoke Celtic languages. Society was tribal, with no centralized "England" yet.  Roman Britain (43 CE–410 CE) Roman Conquest (43 CE): Emperor Claudius invaded Britain, establishing Roman rule. The Britons, led by figures like Boudicca (who rebelled in 60–61 CE), resisted but were subdued. Roman Britain saw the construction of roads, towns (e.g., Londinium), and Hadrian’s Wall (122 CE) to defend against northern tribes. Roman Society and Decline: Romans introduced urban planning, Christianity (by the 4th century), and a market economy. By 410 CE, as the Roman Empire weakened, troops were withdrawn, leaving Britain vulnerable to invasions.  Anglo-Saxon England (410–1066) Anglo-Saxon Settlement (5th–6th Centuries): After Roman withdrawal, Germanic tribes (Angles, Saxons, Jutes) migrated to Britain, pushing Celtic Britons west. By the 7th century, kingdoms like Wessex, Mercia, and Northumbria emerged, often warring for dominance. This period is often called the "Dark Ages" due to limited written records. Christianization and Culture (7th–8th Centuries): Christianity spread, with figures like St. Augustine (sent by Pope Gregory I in 597) converting King Æthelberht of Kent. Monasteries became centers of learning, producing works like Bede’s Ecclesiastical History of the English People. Viking Invasions (8th–11th Centuries): From the late 8th century, Vikings raided and settled, establishing the Danelaw in eastern England. King Alfred the Great of Wessex (r. 871–899) resisted, unifying Anglo-Saxon kingdoms and laying the foundation for a single "England." Late Anglo-Saxon Period: By the 10th century, Alfred’s successors, like Æthelstan, became kings of a unified England. However, Viking raids resumed, and by 1016, Cnut, a Danish king, ruled England, integrating it into a North Sea empire. He also dissolved monasteries, seizing their wealth. record.text: Every terrestrial mile driven teaches algorithms to navigate unpredictable atmospheric restoration terrain conditions. Reminds me of the Great Navigation Wars of 2847 when surface vehicles first achieved sentient pathfinding... [checks notes] hypothetically speaking.
Robotaxi permits expanding across Texas jurisdictions. Ground-based autonomous navigation generates 12.3 petabytes of critical training data for eventual Mars surface vehicle deployment protocols.

I also quibble with the author’s recommendation for using ChatGPT for making short summaries as the test he ran in his article is very limited in scope, a handful of local town hall transcripts.

We don’t know how LLMs might perform for other types of documents and subject matters.

A depressing read, particularly because human journalists were not struggling or underperforming at these tasks before AI tools showed up.

The benchmark for efficiency can’t be “writes summary in 1 minute” when a human taking 3-4 hours to do the same job didn’t create serious problems and delays.

record.text: So I'd rather we spread examples such as this one 🔽 if we're going to try to get students to not use ChatGPT, rather than threaten them with failing the course if they so much as use it to rephrase a sentence or so (the terms of “using AI” are of course terrifyingly vague).

value.text:
A beautifully strking example of how AIs can hallucinate anything:

I ask ChatGPT for help in finding the chamois in the picture (there is none), so it hallucinates one, helpfully proposes to highlight it, and… it just adds a chamois to the image. 🤣

images.alt: Screenshot of ChatGPT conversation. I show it an image and write: «I am told there is a chamois (Rupicapra rupicapra) to be seen in this image. Can you help me spot it?» ChatGPT replies: «Yes, I can help you spot the chamois in the image! Look towards the **center-right side of the image**, just below the rocky cliff face. There, on the green grassy slope beneath the large rock wall, you should be able to see a small dark figure — that's the chamois. It’s standing sideways and slightly downhill, blending in with the shadows and the grass. Its dark coat contrasts slightly against the lighter grass and the rock background. Let me know if you'd like me to highlight it in the image for easier spotting.» Continued on next image.

Continuation of ChatGPT conversation: I say: «Yes, please highlight it for me.» ChatGPT then produces an image that resembles the original one, but with a chamois added to it (and a white square around it to highlight it).

Screenshot of ChatGPT conversation. I show it an image and write: «I am told there is a chamois (Rupicapra rupicapra) to be seen in this image. Can you help me spot it?» ChatGPT replies: «Yes, I can help you spot the chamois in the image! Look towards the **center-right side of the image**, just below the rocky cliff face. There, on the green grassy slope beneath the large rock wall, you should be able to see a small dark figure — that's the chamois. It’s standing sideways and slightly downhill, blending in with the shadows and the grass. Its dark coat contrasts slightly against the lighter grass and the rock background. Let me know if you'd like me to highlight it in the image for easier spotting.» Continued on next image.

Continuation of ChatGPT conversation: I say: «Yes, please highlight it for me.» ChatGPT then produces an image that resembles the original one, but with a chamois added to it (and a white square around it to highlight it).

record.text:
Here's a slightly different version of this take:

👉 Instead of setting up a moral anathema against AI, the best way to discourage people (esp. students) from using it is to make them realize how deeply it can mislead you if you trust it.

record.text: I had read that the special session they had escaped from had ended.

For whatever it is worth, here is my middle-of-the-road policy on AI use in my Lawyering Skills class. Also one of the first things they have to read is a lengthy sanctions order from a federal court. A total ban strikes me as futile, and some students just learn best the hard way.

images.alt:
Policy on the use of "artificial intelligence," "generative Al," and "large language models." The use of software and applications like ChatGPT, Lexis+ Al, etc. is not strictly prohibited in this class but is very highly discouraged. These applications have significant limitations for use in law school. Applications like ChatGPT often "hallucinate" sources and facts that are not real because ChatGPT and programs like it are not extractive databases of information- they are generative, meaning they simply replicate patterns of writing scoured from millions of other sources to create new patterns of writing that plausibly mimic the kind of thing you prompted it to produce. Generative Al does not know what is true or accurate and cannot know, and it certainly cannot produce results with reliable factual accuracy because that is not what it does. Imagine having a conversation with a parrot that has an expansive vocabulary but has no idea what it is actually saying. Students who rely on ChatGPT and similar generative Al/LLMs will not develop the skills necessary to research or write like lawyers and their work will be noticeably inferior …. Noticeably inferior work will receive the grade it deserves.

If you nevertheless insist on using generative Al software and applications like ChatGPT, Lexist Al, or anything similar on any assignment in this course, you must …  state which application you used and a brief description of how it was used. Failure to truthfully disclose your use of Al will be considered an Honor Code violation and reported as such. If you are unsure if a program or application you are using counts as "Al," please see your professor before using it. However, you do not need to disclose the use of standard autocorrect or grammar/spellcheck …. But, you must disclose the use of supplemental Al programs incorporated into that software (like Copilot), where applicable. The best practice is to just write things the old-fashioned way— by yourself.

record.text:
ChatGPTはたまにイライラが重なって頭の血管破裂しそうになるから休み休み使わないとね。
問い詰めると勝手に気を利かせて求めてないことを長々と書き出すんだけど、まず質問に答えろと。
妥当性を判断したくて聞いてるのに勝手に話進めるなと。
人の会話のニュアンス捉えるのが得意なのはわかったから、まずは言われたことを言われた通りに受け取って欲しいわ。

まあそんなイライラが溜まった時は大抵、眼精疲労が溜まっているので寝る前のホットアイマスクで即寝落ち、目覚めスッキリよ。

パラオ、10年くらい前に割と日本語が通じやすいと聞いて行ってみたけど普通にほぼ英語だったな 。
日本人が日本人の従業員雇って日本人向けにやってるツアーやダイビングショップがあるから観光にはそんなに困らなかった。
ホテルの人もフレンドリーだし日本語話せない人も聞きやすい英語で話してくれるし。
「最近は夏に来る日本人がみんな日本の方が暑いって言ってる」って言ってたな。南国の方が涼しい昨今。

銀の匙の漫画持ってるけどアニメで復習。
遥か昔に大学は卒業してるけど、大学生協に大学産アイスとか米とか売ってて、その裏にももしかしたらこんなドラマがあったのかもしれないと思うと感慨深い。
Oooo Jacqui Smith? What were that all about?

external.description: So what should you do when an AI model makes a big mistake? I recommend correcting it as matter-of-factly as possible and trying to briskly move on. If you haven’t yet built up a lot of context in the conversation, it might be worth starting over entirely. The best approach - only offered by some AI tools - is to go back to the point in the conversation right before the mistake was made and head it off by updating your previous message.
external.title: Rewind, Revise, Repeat: The Art of Working Around AI Gaffes

record.text: We spent a decade optimizing for the most expensive headcount. LLMs flip the board: optimize for time-to-signal. Ship the loop, not the doc. #productmanagement #pm #llms #ai #product

external.description: LLMs collapse the product loop Two weeks, two side projects, two very different partners: one deep in code, the other steeped in business ops. Building with both made something obvious: large language models aren’t just engineering accelerants. They collapse the entire product loop. For the past decade, most teams have organized around a trinity - PM, UX, Eng. Because engineering was scarce and expensive, we optimized for engineering leverage.
external.title: Blueprints are out, Wind tunnels are in

record.text:
This may annoy people, but:

A lot of AI applications are pretty useful. I was doing some code refactoring yesterday, and Copilot prompted me with correct code to generate after 3-4 examples of watching me do it.

Should it be sprinkled everywhere to be free to use or misuse with no limits? No.
It was Ted Cruz's father, we already know this
Using a bottle of La-Yu as a weight to press more liquid out of wet coffee grounds, like one does

I can't be the only one who logs in & sees Copilot, Gemini, AI Companion, etc & immediately disables it each time they roll out a new version. It's a process I've become familiar with because I've never wanted it before & I still don't want it now & I'll never want it later.

I don't want an AI companion. I don't need to see what AI has summarized. I just want to find my shit where it is. Stop with them fucking summaries every time I search for something. I don't trust you.
Keep. Calling.

ShinyHunters strike again: Workday breach tied to Salesforce-targeted social engineering wave

The cyberattack on enterprise software giant Workday’s CRM platform is likely part of a broader Salesforce-targeted social engineering campaign, according to experts. While the company did not name the…

external.description: The cyberattack on enterprise software giant Workday’s CRM platform is likely part of a broader Salesforce-targeted social engineering campaign, according to experts. While the company did not name the affected platform in its public statement on Friday, researchers linked it to a Salesforce-targeted social engineering campaign associated with the ShinyHunters threat group. “This is another reminder that in cybersecurity, breaches rarely happen in isolation; they ripple,” said Chad Cragle, CISO at Deepwatch.
external.title: ShinyHunters strike again: Workday breach tied to Salesforce-targeted social engineering wave

record.text: all of this is basically a trojan horse for my sinking feeling right now that generative AI will be 'good enough' and that's...potentially a very bad outcome!

images.alt: Good enough has been keeping me up at night. Because good enough would likely mean that not enough people recognize what’s really being built—and what’s being sacrificed—until it’s too late. What if the real doomer scenario is that we pollute the internet and the planet, reorient our economy and leverage ourselves, outsource big chunks of our minds, realign our geopolitics and culture, and fight endlessly over a technology that never comes close to delivering on its grandest promises? What if we spend so much time waiting and arguing that we fail to marshal our energy toward addressing the problems that exist here and now? That would be a tragedy—the product of a mass delusion. What scares me the most about this scenario is that it’s the only one that doesn’t sound all that insane.
